speaker: Speaker 7
text: Well, he founded the socialist party of America in 1901,

speaker: Speaker 7

speaker: Speaker 7

speaker: Speaker 7

speaker: Speaker 9

speaker: Speaker 7
text: Part 1. The Gilded Cage

speaker: Speaker 9
text: In 1894, when he was 38 years old,

speaker: Speaker 9
text: Eugene Debs went toe-to-toe with a massive company, risking everything.

speaker: Speaker 8
text: This is the event that transformed Debs into a symbol of national discontent.

speaker: Speaker 9
text: At the time, the whole country was feeling an economic depression,

speaker: Speaker 9
text: including the most dominant industry of the day.

speaker: Speaker 9
text: Railroads

speaker: Speaker 9
text: One manufacturer of Railroad cars, the Pullman Palace car company, was really feeling the burn.

speaker: Speaker 9
text: The company was known for introducing a new kind of train car.

speaker: Speaker 8
text: These very luxurious train cars that transform rail travel.

speaker: Speaker 9
text: Chandeliers hung from the ceiling.

speaker: Speaker 9
text: The seats were covered in plush upholstery.

speaker: Speaker 9
text: The walls painted with intricate designs.

speaker: Speaker 9
text: And at night, the cars transformed into a two-story hotel on wheels.

speaker: Speaker 8
text: And all of these cars were built in Holman, Illinois, a very original name for a company town.

speaker: Speaker 9
text: On Chicago's south side, Pullman was a company town through and through.

speaker: Speaker 8
text: Basically, factory workers who built the cars had to rent their homes from the company.

speaker: Speaker 8
text: By their groceries from company stores, send their kids to company schools,

speaker: Speaker 8
text: who's even a company church.

speaker: Speaker 8
text: And George Pullman, the guy, had justified the community as an experiment in benevolent capitalism.

speaker: Speaker 8
text: Like, look at the brick homes, the paved streets, the trash collection, the indoor plumbing,

speaker: Speaker 8
text: what a clean, orderly way to live that are results in happier and more productive workers.

speaker: Speaker 9
text: And the living standards were better than average.

speaker: Speaker 8
text: But it was also described as a sort of gilded cage.

speaker: Speaker 8
text: Because workers feared speaking out about their working conditions, because you could just get fired.

speaker: Speaker 8
text: You know, there's no protections for you at this point.

speaker: Speaker 7
text: During the economic downturn, things went from bad to worse for these workers.

speaker: Speaker 8
text: In order to keep turning a profit, and not cut executive salaries or shareholder payouts,

speaker: Speaker 7
text: Holman slashed worker wages.

speaker: Speaker 7
text: In some cases, by up to half, without cutting rents, grocery costs, or utility costs.

speaker: Speaker 7
text: So workers just couldn't make ends meet.

speaker: Speaker 7
text: And they were getting desperate.

speaker: Speaker 8
text: Workers had been feinting on the job, having not eaten in days after feeding their kids.

speaker: Speaker 8
text: That's how awful the situation was.

speaker: Speaker 8
text: There's a famous political cartoon of George Pullman, pushing the crank that is squeezing

speaker: Speaker 8
text: a worker between these two massive stones.

speaker: Speaker 8
text: And it's as low wages and as high housing costs.

speaker: Speaker 8
text: My name is Allison Dirk. I am the director at the Eugene V. Debs Museum in TeraHot.

speaker: Speaker 7
text: As the Pullman workers grew more and more frustrated, many decided to join the American Railway Union,

speaker: Speaker 7
text: the ARU, a powerful industrial union with as many as 250,000 members in 27 states

speaker: Speaker 7
text: that was founded and run by Eugene Debs.

speaker: Speaker 6
text: And that's what led him into really the most important labor conflict of the 19th century in the

speaker: Speaker 7
text: United States. This is Ernest Freiberg. He's a history professor at the University of Tennessee

speaker: Speaker 6
text: in Maxwell. And I'm the author of Democracy's Prisoner, Eugene Debs, The Great War, and the Right to

speaker: Speaker 7
text: In May 1894, 3,000 Pullman workers, after months of being fed up, lay down their tools,

speaker: Speaker 6
text: walk out of the shops, say, Pullman, we can't go back to our jobs until you reconsider

speaker: Speaker 6
text: a wage as encoder rents so we can afford to live and feed our children.

speaker: Speaker 6
text: Pullman wouldn't budge, insisting that there was nothing to arbitrate. That's the quote.

speaker: Speaker 6
text: After this refusal to negotiate, the workers with debt support, called for a massive strike.

speaker: Speaker 3
text: Every railroad employee of the country should take his stand against the corporations in this fight

speaker: Speaker 3
text: for if it should be lost, corporations will have despotic sway and all employees will be reduced to a condition

speaker: Speaker 3
text: scarcely removed above chattel slavery.

speaker: Speaker 7
text: The New York Times reported the labor powers have spoken and the most tremendous strike known to history

speaker: Speaker 7
text: will be inaugurated tomorrow when the evening whistles blow and a hundred thousand men abandon their work

speaker: Speaker 7
text: not to return. It is said until the Pullman boycott is settled.

speaker: Speaker 6
text: This is huge. This is huge. Debs is in practically every major paper at this point when

text: basking him as dictator Debs, but also as the anarchists and it's like pick one,

speaker: Speaker 6
text: you can't be an anarchist and a dictator.

speaker: Speaker 7

speaker: Speaker 6
text: And that effectively is a shutdown of the railroads.

speaker: Speaker 4

text: Approximately 30 workers were killed.

speaker: Speaker 7
text: He got a job working on a railroad in East St. Louis, and was shocked by what he found there.

speaker: Speaker 6
text: He witnessed real poverty, that he hadn't quite experienced or been witnessed to in Terahode.

speaker: Speaker 6
text: He wrote to his parents that it made his heart ache to go along with some of the main streets in the city,

text: and see men, women, and children begging for something to eat.

speaker: Speaker 6
text: And he invited to his sisters and brother that they should appreciate their comfortable home and understanding parents.

speaker: Speaker 6
text: I did not, he confessed, until I came over here.

speaker: Speaker 7

speaker: Speaker 7
text: And despite his parents' insistence that he come home, he stayed in East St. Louis.

speaker: Speaker 3
text: He's a star. Eugene Debs' role in the Pullman Strike and the Liberty Speech in Chicago

speaker: Speaker 3
text: made many see him as the champion of the working person in America. He was a fiery populist who

speaker: Speaker 3
text: was unafraid to challenge big business and this fame gave him a path into national politics.

speaker: Speaker 3
text: A path he initially didn't want to take. He is courted by some different political groups

speaker: Speaker 4
text: including the populists who wanted Debs to run for president in 96.

speaker: Speaker 3
text: Quick side note, the populist party, officially the People's Party, was established in 1892

speaker: Speaker 3
text: to represent the economic interest of farmers and urban workers. They began running candidates

speaker: Speaker 3
text: for president that same year. Eugene Debs was a supporter of the party. But as he started flirting

speaker: Speaker 3
text: with socialism, his feelings towards the populists started to change. He felt that their proposals

speaker: Speaker 3
text: didn't go far enough for workers. So when they wanted to nominate him in 1896, he rejected

speaker: Speaker 4
text: the populist party's nomination. They end up endorsing William Jennings Bryan.

speaker: Speaker 6
text: Eugene Debs campaigned for Bryan. But when he lost the election, this is the last straw.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: By 1897, just a couple months after Bryan's defeat in the election, Debs said the issue is

speaker: Speaker 4
text: socialism versus capitalism. I am for socialism because I am for humanity. We have been cursed with

speaker: Speaker 4
text: the reign of gold long enough. Money no longer constitutes a proper basis for civilization. We are

speaker: Speaker 4
text: on the eve of universal change. This is Debs first endorsement of socialism.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: So he basically argued America has this long revolutionary tradition, this long radical tradition

speaker: Speaker 2
text: which has been the force of progress that has expanded democracy. And socialism is simply the next step.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: The emerging industrial corporate system is robbing people of their democratic birthright. And

speaker: Speaker 2
text: this is the next big obstacle. And socialism is going to speak to that. Not as a radical idea from

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Europe, but rather this is the homegrown natural next step for the evolution of American democracy.

speaker: Speaker 6
text: Debs begins going around the country holding rallies in front of large crowds.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: This gave him a great opportunity to spread the gospel of socialism.

speaker: Speaker 6
text: There were a bunch of different factions of socialist in America.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: The socialist party was a coalition of very different kinds of people who had come to socialism

speaker: Speaker 4
text: in very different ways. All these different factions and descendants in between.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: The Greenwich Village, Bohemian radicals, the painters and artists in San Francisco,

speaker: Speaker 2
text: people like Jack London, up to Sinclair. But it was also the farmers of Oklahoma who had been

speaker: Speaker 2
text: part of the populist movement and felt like the real problem in America was that capital was

speaker: Speaker 2
text: getting in the way of their business. And also German immigrants who had come from socialist

speaker: Speaker 2
text: tradition in Europe. Jewish garment workers in the east side of New York also had a socialist

speaker: Speaker 4
text: radical tradition. And Debs was the unifying figure around which different wings and sections of

speaker: Speaker 2
text: the party could actually rally. Debs had the ability to speak to all of them. They themselves

speaker: Speaker 2
text: could not necessarily speak the same language to each other, but somehow Debs managed to engage

speaker: Speaker 2
text: and speak to all of them. What made him especially potent was the fact that he transcribed that

speaker: Speaker 2
text: socialist tradition into an American grain.

speaker: Speaker 6
text: In 1900, Debs ran as a socialist for president. And in 1901, he founded a political party,

speaker: Speaker 6
text: the socialist party of America, uniting all the socialist groups under one banner.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: He joked around a lot about how like if we ever stood a chance of electing a president,

speaker: Speaker 4
text: don't run me, I would make a bad president. More critical for Debs was raising class consciousness.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: He once workers to see themselves as workers, not middle class, not as temporarily embarrassed

speaker: Speaker 4
text: as workers with more in common than we have different. He considered himself a preacher,

speaker: Speaker 6
text: not an administrator, but the socialist party was part of a larger movement. And Debs knew that

speaker: Speaker 6
text: he was driven by the ideas and policy proposals they were putting forward. Things like more support

speaker: Speaker 1
text: for early childhood education. The 40-hour work week. Old age pensions. Well-fair programs for

speaker: Speaker 2
text: the poor or worker safety protections. These are things that were radical third party innovations

speaker: Speaker 6
text: when they were first proposed by the socialists. He understood that he could use his celebrity to be

speaker: Speaker 6
text: a presidential nominee that would raise a profile of all of these ideas. That's ultimately what

speaker: Speaker 4
text: propels him into the nomination is the sense of responsibility to this movement and to the party

speaker: Speaker 4
text: recognizing that he would probably be the most effective figure to do that task.

speaker: Speaker 3
text: So in 1904, he began running for president as the candidate of the socialist party of America.

speaker: Speaker 3
text: He also worked as a columnist where his voice was amplified even more.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: And you can't talk about Debs in the 19 Outs without the appeal to reason,

speaker: Speaker 4
text: which at its peak was the most popular political newspaper in the nation with half a million

speaker: Speaker 4
text: subscriptions. It was a socialist weekly, explicitly socialist, published out of little Gerard

speaker: Speaker 4

speaker: Speaker 2
text: an important force, an important voice, but they were still a minority and still demonized right

speaker: Speaker 4

speaker: Speaker 2
text: that makes sense. Socialism was quite dangerous and Debs would have considered himself to be a

speaker: Speaker 2
text: dangerous man because he was looking to radically change the system and that involved public ownership

speaker: Speaker 2
text: of the means of production. That it wasn't simply a matter of regulating business, but that a lot

speaker: Speaker 2
text: of business was drawing on what they considered to be public resources, the land and the forests and

speaker: Speaker 2
text: the minerals and that these things ought to be collectively owned and more democratically controlled.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Debs and others who were pushing this idea were actually far more radical than anything that now

speaker: Speaker 2
text: passes for socialism at least under our current conversation.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: You know, there's hostility, but I think Debs is also really adept at taking socialist concepts

speaker: Speaker 4

speaker: Speaker 4
text: He's this corn fed huzure, right? So he's able to kind of make these ideas a little bit more

speaker: Speaker 4
text: palatable to not just like people in cities, but people in rural America too.

text: Meanwhile World War One was beginning

speaker: Speaker 5
text: And as troops headed to the front lines the vibe in the US was very different

speaker: Speaker 3
text: Most Americans are saying this is something we want nothing to do with

speaker: Speaker 3
text: You know, this is an era when one-third of Americans are either immigrants or the children of immigrants and different groups had different loyalties

speaker: Speaker 3
text: The Irish in America were not interested in going to war to defend the English

speaker: Speaker 3
text: Many Jews in America were not interested in an alliance that included Russia

speaker: Speaker 3
text: They had escaped persecution from Russia and one of the largest immigrant groups in America was the German Americans

speaker: Speaker 3
text: And of course they were conflicted about going to war against their ancestral homeland as well

speaker: Speaker 5
text: And people like Debs who were born and raised in the American Heartland

speaker: Speaker 3
text: Also had their reservations. There's a sort of long isolationist tradition going all the way back to the very beginning

speaker: Speaker 3
text: George Washington's argument was we should have no foreign entangling alliances

speaker: Speaker 3
text: Right and that the Atlantic Ocean was there to keep us out of

speaker: Speaker 3
text: European disagreements

speaker: Speaker 3

speaker: Speaker 4
text: During these days that are to try men's souls, you know

speaker: Speaker 3

speaker: Speaker 4

speaker: Speaker 4

speaker: Speaker 4
text: In

text: 1917 after several German attacks on American ships

text: The US decided it had to get involved in the war

speaker: Speaker 3

speaker: Speaker 3

speaker: Speaker 3
text: The socialist draft of declaration which basically says

speaker: Speaker 3
text: This is a rich man's war and a poor man's fight and the socialist party will be united

speaker: Speaker 3

speaker: Speaker 3

speaker: Speaker 7

speaker: Speaker 7
text: Buck the party position the endorsed the war they're the war socialist

speaker: Speaker 3
text: They say this is a big mistake we are going to be branded as unpatriotic

speaker: Speaker 3
text: If we do this

speaker: Speaker 3
text: And we should trust that you know Wilson had this idea that which was actually

speaker: Speaker 3
text: Something that appealed to the socialists this idea that after the war

speaker: Speaker 3
text: There would be this congress of nations the league of nations idea that diplomacy would be more open

speaker: Speaker 3
text: And there would be collective security

speaker: Speaker 8
text: Still most socialists remained opposed to the war

speaker: Speaker 8
text: The radical socialist press was filled with anti-war articles and a fleet of speakers traveled the country making anti-war speeches

speaker: Speaker 8
text: Including their secret weapon Eugene Debs

speaker: Unknown Speaker
text: And

speaker: Speaker 6
text: That begins a

speaker: Speaker 6
text: Kind of a revival for Gene Debs. He's not well

speaker: Speaker 6
text: But he simply says I can't let this go by

speaker: Speaker 5
text: On April 6th 1917 the US entered the Great War and keep in mind up to this point

speaker: Speaker 5
text: Many Americans still favored neutrality

speaker: Speaker 5
text: They wanted no part in this foreign conflict

speaker: Speaker 5
text: The Wilson administration knew that in order for the war effort to succeed they had to change the narrative

speaker: Speaker 5
text: So they launched a massive campaign unlike anything the country had seen before

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Hiring the best artists, filmmakers and historians and scholars and movie stars.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: To go out and pitch the idea that the Germans are demonic villains and that the allies are not just another set of imperial powers out for their own game, but are actually our noble friends.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: And we need to support them.

speaker: Speaker 3
text: The campaign was a success. The country became consumed by the war.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Stirred up in enormous war frenzy with a lot of vigilante violence against people like socialist anti-war speakers and religious pacifists and so forth.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: And a lot of it was stimulated by this propaganda campaign.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: The other side of that, Congress passes the Espionage Act of 1917, which made a federal crime punishable by up to 20 years in prison to criticize the war or the government.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: Things socialist were already doing by this point.

speaker: Speaker 5
text: Thousands of socialists were tracked and arrested. Their newspapers were ransacked and shut down.

speaker: Speaker 6
text: I realize that in speaking to you this afternoon there are certain limitations placed upon the right of free speech.

speaker: Speaker 6
text: I must be exceedingly careful, prudent as to what I say and even more careful and prudent as to how I say it.

speaker: Speaker 6
text: I may not be able to say all I think, but I am not going to say anything that I do not think.

speaker: Speaker 6
text: I would rather a thousand times be a free soul in jail than to be a sick of it, coward in the streets.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: If you know the first thing about Jean-Devs, he is not about to cave on his principles.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: He knew at that time that federal agents were following him when he gave speeches. They were federal agents in the audience.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: And went on to give his most famous speech. When 101 years ago last June in Canton, Ohio, 1918.

speaker: Speaker 6
text: The working class who fight all the battles, the working class who make the supreme sacrifices, the working class who freely shed their blood and furnished the corpses, have never yet had a voice.

speaker: Speaker 6
text: In either declaring war or making peace. It is the ruling class that invariably does both.

speaker: Speaker 7
text: Devs argues that the war itself is a war of competing capitalist organizations.

speaker: Speaker 6
text: Everywhere they are moving toward democracy and the dawn, marching toward the sunrise. Their faces all a glow with the light of the coming day.

speaker: Speaker 6
text: These are the socialists, the most zealous and enthusiastic crusaders the world has ever known.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: So the general theme of this very long speech is democracy.

speaker: Speaker 7
text: He never migrates away from American values.

speaker: Speaker 7
text: He criticizes the fancy capitalists, all of that sort of stuff. But he is not embarrassed about talking about American traditions, about American democracy.

speaker: Speaker 7
text: He sees it as a valued asset that is under serious attack.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: It is interesting that what Deb said during the speech was not reprinted because many newspapers were worried that if they reprinted, they themselves might be punished by the government for allowing these sentiments into their pages.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: So nobody actually knew just what Deb's had said at that point.

speaker: Speaker 5
text: Two weeks later, Devs was arrested.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: We have to talk about Devs and his sentencing hearing at Cleveland because it is some of the most profound stuff he ever said.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: He has already been convicted of violating this edition law. He knows he is going to go to prison. He just doesn't know how long for.

speaker: Speaker 7
text: The trial is one of the oddest things in the world in the sense that I think half the court room, court officials, I should say, actually like Trump,

speaker: Speaker 7
text: they didn't agree with him at all, but they liked him. But it didn't stop the process.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Devs himself refuses to apologize.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: And he got the chance to address the judge in the jury.

speaker: Speaker 7
text: His whole final speech to the judge is just a wonderful framing of his life's work.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: He said, Your Honor, years ago, I recognized my kinship with all living beings and made it my mind that I was not one bit better than the meanest on earth.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: I said then and I say now that while there is a lower class, I am in it.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: While there is a criminal element, I am of it. And while there is a soul in prison, I am not free.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: You know, this is one of those great moments in America where the person on trial manages to put the law itself on trial.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: And he basically argues, you know, I have every right to speak on the most important issue of the day and that's what I was doing.

speaker: Speaker 7
text: His last comment to the judge, he says, Let the people everywhere take heart and hope for the cross's bending, the midnight is passing.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: Don is on its way. Relief and rest are close at hand.

speaker: Speaker 7
text: And then he thanked the judge and the court for their kindness and said, Your Honor, I'm prepared for your sentence.

speaker: Speaker 7
text: He realized that the people he was arguing against and indeed fighting against, were also Americans.

speaker: Speaker 7
text: He recognized that he didn't like them, he didn't agree with them. He would fight them to his last breath.

speaker: Speaker 7
text: But he didn't dehumanize them.

speaker: Speaker 5
text: Debs was sentenced to 10 years in a federal prison.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: The trial was widely covered and it was considered to be one of the important test cases of the Espionage Act.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Some are saying, Look, we should acknowledge that we really overreached in this case.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: The Espionage Act was wrong and now is the time to say so.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: This goes to the Supreme Court and Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr., who we recognize and remember as a great advocate for free speech, was actually the person who wrote for the unanimous opinion sending Debs to prison.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Basically they're arguing that Congress has the right to put public safety over free speech in times of national crisis.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: This is where this idea of clear and present danger enters into our vocabulary that essentially free speech means one thing in times of peace and another thing in times of war and that's just too bad.

speaker: Speaker 3
text: Meanwhile, the perception of socialism in the US was changing.

speaker: Speaker 3
text: After the 1917 Bolshevik Revolution in Russia, a class-based uprising that ushered in a global wave of socialist thinking,

speaker: Speaker 3
text: socialism was reframed as something foreign and dangerous.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: So this is our first major red scare.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: The red scare, the demonization of socialism that occurs.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: And if you think about the cultural and political impact that McCarthyism had in the 50s, this is that, but in the 19 teens and in the earliest 20s too.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Both of those things have very effectively convinced many Americans that socialism is an alien force rather than something that has this long-rich indigenous history.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: This is the end of the socialist party as Debs knew it at its peak and it would just never recover it.

speaker: Speaker 5
text: By 1920, Debs watched from prison as free speech became the issue of the day.

speaker: Speaker 5
text: An amnesty movement was beginning to take shape.

speaker: Speaker 5
text: The roots of the ACLU were forming and for many, Eugene Debs was the symbol of democracy under threat.

speaker: Speaker 5
text: That's why even as he sat in a prison cell in poor health, the socialist party chose Debs to run for president again.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: They're convinced that if they can run Debs for president from prison, that what they will do is essentially make his imprisonment a national issue that will essentially put it on the ballot.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: This is a referendum on the First Amendment and they were inviting Americans to cast a protest vote.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: They play it up as much as possible.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: The campaign button for the socialist party in 1920 didn't have his name on it. It just said for president.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: Vote for convict 9653.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: With a picture of Debs in his prison uniform in front of the Atlanta federal penitentiary, those are in our gift shop if anybody wants one, but in any case.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: The warden allows Debs to come out of prison and stand on the front steps of the prison to receive the nomination.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: There he is in his prison denim. Normally he's dressed in a conservative three-piece suit.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: It really looks more like a banker than what we think of as a working class radical.

speaker: Speaker 2
text: There he is in his prison denims receiving the nomination from...

speaker: Speaker 1
text: what's left of the socialist party at that point.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: Although there were only about 20,000 registered socialists left,

speaker: Speaker 4
text: Debs got nearly one million votes in the election.

speaker: Speaker 6
text: His supporters outside the prison set him letters and boxes of fruit, candy and tobacco.

speaker: Speaker 6
text: They also wrote petitions to the government.

speaker: Speaker 4
text: And after serving two years and eight months in prison, he was released.

speaker: Speaker 7
text: When he comes out of the prison, the director of the prison had opened the cell doors,

speaker: Speaker 7
text: which is a no-no in most gels, to say goodbye.

speaker: Speaker 7
text: And indeed, he's walking down this curved pathway out to the red quarries.

speaker: Speaker 7
text: And he turns into a sack.

speaker: Speaker 5
text: Jean came back to Teraho and the New York Times reported that 50,000 of Debs supporters

speaker: Speaker 5
text: greeted him at the train station a few blocks from the house and escorted him back to his home on

speaker: Speaker 5
text: eighth straight. I mean, why was the right word there? Because that's almost Teraho's population

speaker: Speaker 5
text: then and today. And she gave you an idea of the scope and scale of how loved Debs was.

speaker: Speaker 5
text: It's not an exaggeration to say that he was considered a martyr for his cause by his supporters

speaker: Speaker 5
text: and never recovered from the toll that prison took on his health.

speaker: Speaker 7
text: When I think of Jean Debs' legacy, I think of people. I think of Dorothy Day,

speaker: Speaker 7
text: the Catholic worker. I think of Norman Thomas, the socialist presidential candidate in the

speaker: Speaker 7
text: late 20s and early 30s. I think of Michael Harrington, social activist and writer and,

speaker: Speaker 7
text: et cetera, in the 60s, 70s and 80s.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: I think many people who are sympathetic to the left ever since then look back on that as a

speaker: Speaker 1
text: golden moment where a growing number of people could conceive that America could be socialist.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Socialism, you know, it's a third party succeeded in accomplishing many of the things

speaker: Speaker 1
text: that we now take for granted as just part of the liberal state. You know, the social

speaker: Speaker 1
text: safety network, the government oversight of health and welfare, some controls over the

speaker: Speaker 1
text: financial system. Those are all part of the socialist program that were adopted first by the

speaker: Speaker 1
text: progressives in the early 20th century and then many of them by the New Deal and some of them

speaker: Speaker 1
text: ultimately by the great society programs in the 60s. So there's this long legacy of socialist ideas

speaker: Speaker 1
text: at a very important moment when America was facing the beginnings of this ongoing industrial

speaker: Speaker 5
text: revolution. If you boil down his legacy and what it means to us now, it's these two concepts of

speaker: Speaker 5
text: optimism and solidarity and I hope that's not cliche because devs as an optimist, it wasn't this

speaker: Speaker 5
text: polyanna like, oh, it's going to be okay. Everything's going to work out in the end type of thing.

speaker: Speaker 5
text: He understood that it was a struggle and that people would have to actually put effort into making

speaker: Speaker 5
text: this change happen. But he did believe that regular people are capable of enacting huge changes

speaker: Speaker 5
text: that change the course of history.

speaker: Speaker 6
